test_metadata.test_title: External Sector, BoP, Trade and Capital Flows - Practice MCQ Test
test_metadata.subject: Indian Economy
test_metadata.sub_topic: BoP, Trade Policy, Exchange Rate, FDI/FPI, External Debt
test_metadata.description: UPSC-oriented MCQs on Balance of Payments, exchange rate regimes, foreign trade, FDI/FPI and external vulnerability of the Indian economy.

questions.question_text: Which of the following best describes the Balance of Payments (BoP) of a country?

options.option_text: Statement of all financial transactions of the government only
Record of all economic transactions between residents of a country and the rest of the world in a given period
Statement of all domestic income and expenditure
Only record of exports and imports of goods

questions.question_text: Which of the following accounts is NOT a part of the current account in BoP?

options.option_text: Exports and imports of goods
Exports and imports of services
Income from investment and wages
Foreign direct investment inflows

questions.question_text: Which of the following transactions is recorded in the capital account of BoP?

options.option_text: Merchandise exports
Tourism receipts
External commercial borrowings (ECBs)
Private remittances from abroad

questions.question_text: A persistent deficit in the current account of BoP is generally a cause of concern because it may indicate:

options.option_text: Excessive domestic savings
Excess of imports and income payments over exports and income receipts
Complete absence of capital flows
Only a temporary change in forex reserves with no macro impact

questions.question_text: Which of the following is TRUE about India’s BoP accounting identity at the broad level?

options.option_text: Current account + Capital account = 0 always, with no balancing item
Current account + Capital account + Errors and omissions = Change in forex reserves (with sign convention)
Only current account is relevant; capital account is not recorded
BoP does not include errors and omissions

questions.question_text: Which one of the following is an invisible item in the current account of India’s BoP?

options.option_text: Export of software services
Export of crude oil
Import of machinery
Import of gold

questions.question_text: Workers’ remittances from abroad to India are recorded under which part of the BoP?

options.option_text: Capital account – FDI
Current account – Transfers
Capital account – Portfolio investment
Financial derivatives account

questions.question_text: A depreciation of the domestic currency (under a flexible exchange rate) tends to:

options.option_text: Make exports cheaper and imports costlier
Make exports costlier and imports cheaper
Have no impact on trade flows
Always lead to current account surplus immediately

questions.question_text: Which of the following best describes 'managed float' or 'managed flexible' exchange rate regime followed by many emerging economies including India conceptually?

options.option_text: Completely fixed exchange rate against one currency
Purely market-determined exchange rate with no central bank intervention
Market-determined rate with occasional central bank intervention to reduce volatility
Central bank administratively sets the rate daily without market forces

questions.question_text: Which of the following is NOT typically a component of India’s foreign exchange reserves?

options.option_text: Foreign currency assets
Gold holdings of RBI
Special Drawing Rights (SDRs)
Shares of domestic public sector units held by government

questions.question_text: Foreign Direct Investment (FDI) is best distinguished from Foreign Portfolio Investment (FPI) by the fact that FDI generally:

options.option_text: Is of very short-term speculative nature only
Does not involve any ownership of assets
Involves long-term interest and control in an enterprise
Is always routed through multilateral agencies only

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a likely advantage of FDI for a developing country like India?

options.option_text: Reduction in competition
Access to foreign capital, technology and management practices
Guaranteed elimination of current account deficit
Automatic increase in foreign exchange reserves without any liabilities

questions.question_text: Which of the following best explains 'terms of trade' in external sector context?

options.option_text: Ratio of tax revenue to GDP
Ratio of export prices to import prices
Ratio of exports to imports by volume
Difference between exports and imports in value terms

questions.question_text: A country is said to experience 'trade deficit' when:

options.option_text: Exports of goods exceed imports of goods
Imports of goods exceed exports of goods
Capital inflows exceed capital outflows
Foreign exchange reserves are rising

questions.question_text: Which international institution primarily deals with rules of trade between nations and settlement of trade disputes?

options.option_text: International Monetary Fund
World Bank
World Trade Organization
United Nations Conference on Trade and Development

questions.question_text: The IMF’s primary role in the external sector of member countries is to:

options.option_text: Provide long-term project loans for infrastructure
Provide short- to medium-term balance of payments support
Act as a world trade dispute settlement body
Decide domestic tax policy of members

questions.question_text: Special Drawing Rights (SDRs) are best described as:

options.option_text: A currency used by EU only
An international reserve asset created by IMF
A form of World Bank loan
A freely traded private cryptocurrency

questions.question_text: Which of the following would directly worsen India’s merchandise trade balance, ceteris paribus?

options.option_text: Increase in international crude oil prices
Increase in IT service exports
Increase in workers’ remittances
Tourism receipts rising

questions.question_text: A surge in short-term portfolio capital inflows to India is MOST likely to cause, other things equal:

options.option_text: Depreciation of the rupee
Appreciation pressure on the rupee
No change in exchange rate
Reduction in forex reserves

questions.question_text: Which of the following correctly explains 'exchange rate pass-through' to inflation in an import-dependent economy?

options.option_text: Exchange rate changes have no effect on domestic prices
Depreciation of currency raises domestic prices of imports and may raise inflation
Appreciation of currency always raises inflation
Exchange rate affects only exports, not prices

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a major risk associated with high dependence on volatile portfolio flows for financing current account deficit?

options.option_text: They are always long-term and stable
Sudden reversal can cause sharp currency depreciation and BoP stress
They eliminate any need for forex reserves
They remove all external vulnerability permanently

questions.question_text: In the context of external debt sustainability, which of the following indicators is often used as a critical ratio?

options.option_text: External debt to forex reserves
Tax to GDP ratio
Agricultural GDP to total GDP
Public expenditure to GDP

questions.question_text: Which among the following is often the largest component of India’s service exports, helping to offset merchandise trade deficit?

options.option_text: Transportation services
Travel and tourism services
Software and IT-enabled services
Construction services only

questions.question_text: Which of the following policies can directly help improve the current account balance of India in the medium term?

options.option_text: Boosting export competitiveness and moderating non-essential imports
Only increasing external commercial borrowings
Reducing forex reserves
Strictly banning all capital inflows

questions.question_text: Which of the following is an example of a 'non-debt creating' capital flow in BoP?

options.option_text: External commercial borrowing
IMF credit
Foreign Direct Investment (FDI)
Sovereign external bonds

questions.question_text: Which of the following statements regarding 'rupee convertibility' is correct conceptually?

options.option_text: Current account convertibility allows free exchange for trade in goods and services
Capital account convertibility refers to complete absence of any controls on foreign loans only
Current account convertibility is about FDI policy
Capital account convertibility deals only with tourism transactions

questions.question_text: India accepted current account convertibility broadly following which global agreement or recommendation era?

options.option_text: Bretton Woods conference of 1944
Post-1991 reforms and IMF Article VIII obligations
Only after joining WTO in 1995
Only after adopting GST

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a typical objective of India’s Foreign Trade Policy (FTP)?

options.option_text: Only import substitution with bans on all imports
Promotion of exports, employment and value addition while rationalising imports
Fixing domestic MSP for all crops
Determining repo rate and CRR

questions.question_text: A 'swap line' arrangement between central banks mainly helps countries to:

options.option_text: Swap domestic bonds for equity shares
Access each other's currency in times of liquidity stress
Swap fiscal deficits for surpluses
Swap domestic public debt with private debt

questions.question_text: A large stock of foreign exchange reserves provides which of the following benefits to a country like India?

options.option_text: Removes any need for exports
Acts as a buffer against external shocks and improves investor confidence
Automatically eliminates fiscal deficit
Makes domestic savings unnecessary

questions.question_text: Which one of the following trends would generally reduce India’s vulnerability on the external sector front, ceteris paribus?

options.option_text: Rising short-term external debt
Higher share of non-debt creating flows like FDI in capital account
Falling forex reserves
Widening current account deficit financed by volatile FPI

questions.question_text: Devaluation of domestic currency under a fixed exchange rate system is generally used to:

options.option_text: Discourage exports and encourage imports
Encourage exports and discourage imports
Have no impact on BoP
Only reduce fiscal deficit

questions.question_text: Which of the following describes 'dumping' in international trade?

options.option_text: Exporting goods at prices lower than their normal value in home market
Exporting only primary commodities
Importing goods at high tariffs
Dumping waste materials abroad legally

questions.question_text: Anti-dumping duties are usually imposed by a country to:

options.option_text: Promote dumping of its own goods abroad
Protect domestic industry from unfairly low-priced imports
Boost fiscal deficit
Provide subsidies to exporters directly

questions.question_text: Which of the following is an example of a 'non-tariff barrier' to trade?

options.option_text: Import duty
Quantitative restrictions and stringent standards
Export tax
Customs duty

questions.question_text: In India’s external sector statistics, the 'invisibles surplus' refers to the situation when:

options.option_text: Exports of goods exceed imports of goods
Net receipts from services, income and transfers exceed payments
Capital inflows exceed capital outflows
External debt exceeds forex reserves

questions.question_text: Which of the following is generally a major source of India’s invisibles surplus?

options.option_text: Oil imports
Gold imports
IT and business process outsourcing services
Import of machinery

questions.question_text: Which of the following policy choices would be MOST consistent with promoting export-led growth for India?

options.option_text: High protectionism and inward-looking trade strategy
Improving logistics, trade facilitation and competitiveness of manufacturing and services
Maintaining high transaction costs at ports
Restricting all trade to primary goods only

questions.question_text: Which of the following is typically considered an advantage of a flexible exchange rate regime for a country like India?

options.option_text: Automatic insulation from any external shock
Allowing exchange rate to act as a shock absorber adjusting to external imbalances
Complete elimination of BoP crises forever
Fixing the currency permanently to the US dollar

questions.question_text: Which of the following would directly improve India’s Net International Investment Position (NIIP) over time?

options.option_text: Increasing external liabilities faster than external assets
Increasing acquisition of foreign assets and reducing growth in external liabilities
Relying exclusively on short-term external borrowing
Running very high current account deficits financed by debt

questions.question_text: Which of the following is an example of 'sovereign external debt' of India?

options.option_text: Loan taken by a private Indian company from a foreign bank
Loan taken by Government of India from World Bank
Loan taken by an Indian household from domestic bank
Deposit of NRIs in Indian banks

questions.question_text: Which one of the following would help reduce the impact of oil price shocks on India’s external sector over the long run?

options.option_text: Increasing dependence on imported crude oil
Diversifying energy sources and promoting renewables and efficiency
Keeping domestic fuel prices artificially fixed forever
Discouraging public transport and promoting only private vehicles

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a major risk of 'original sin' problem often discussed in external debt literature for emerging economies?

options.option_text: Inability to borrow domestically in domestic currency
Inability to borrow externally in domestic currency, leading to currency mismatch risk
Inability to borrow in foreign currency
Inability to export primary commodities

questions.question_text: Which of the following developments would MOST LIKELY indicate an improvement in India’s external sector health?

options.option_text: Widening trade deficit with no rise in invisibles surplus
Narrowing current account deficit along with rising forex reserves
Sharp fall in FDI inflows
Rising share of short-term external debt in total debt

questions.question_text: Which of the following best describes 'capital flight' in external sector context?

options.option_text: Gradual rise in FDI
Sudden and large-scale outflow of capital due to loss of confidence
Increase in remittances
Increase in tourism receipts

questions.question_text: Which of the following policy mix is most appropriate to handle a BoP crisis triggered by a large current account deficit and falling reserves in the short run?

options.option_text: Expansionary fiscal and expansionary monetary policy
Contractionary monetary policy, some fiscal tightening and external financing support
Unlimited money printing to buy foreign exchange
Imposing complete ban on all exports

questions.question_text: Which of the following correctly captures the role of RBI in India’s external sector management?

options.option_text: RBI directly negotiates all trade agreements
RBI manages foreign exchange reserves and intervenes in forex market to reduce volatility
RBI decides customs tariff structure
RBI administers all export promotion schemes

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a logical implication of Marshall–Lerner condition for a currency depreciation to improve trade balance?

options.option_text: Sum of price elasticities of demand for exports and imports should be greater than 1
Exports and imports should both be perfectly inelastic
Only exports should respond to prices
Only imports should respond to prices

questions.question_text: Which of the following would help India move up the global value chain in external trade in the long run?

options.option_text: Focusing only on low-skill, low-value assembly work
Investing in skills, technology, R&D and high-value services and manufacturing
Discouraging innovation and R&D
Restricting all FDI inflows

questions.question_text: In the context of Indian Economy, 'external sector stability' would MOST appropriately refer to a situation where:

options.option_text: Current account deficit is financed mainly by short-term debt and volatile flows
External debt and current account deficit are at sustainable levels, adequately covered by forex reserves and non-debt flows
There is no trade at all with rest of the world
The country has zero forex reserves always
